article_title: Obamacare Stability Rests On Shaky Risk Adjustment

article_metadata.description: The permanent form of "premium stabilization" in the Affordable Care Act is something called "Risk Adjustment." It theoretically makes it possible to offer, as Obamacare does, choice in health insurance benefits. But it doesn't work well unless government can accurately predict an individual's medical costs. So far, the Obama administration's models for doing this aren't doing very well either in an absolute sense or relative to what they hoped for when the ACA got started. This spells trouble for Obamacare stability.
article_metadata.author: The Apothecary
